cases.title: Sinus Bradycardia
key_features: Normal P waves before each QRS
cases.clinical_context: Common in athletes, vagal stimulation, hypothyroidism, medication effect (beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers)
cases.management: Usually benign. Treat if symptomatic (dizziness, syncope, hypotension). Consider pacing if severe.

cases.title: Atrial Fibrillation
cases.clinical_context: Most common sustained arrhythmia. Associated with stroke risk, heart failure, valvular disease
cases.management: Rate control (beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers), rhythm control (cardioversion), anticoagulation (CHA₂DS₂-VASc score)

cases.title: Atrial Flutter
key_features: Best seen in inferior leads (II, III, aVF)
cases.clinical_context: Often coexists with atrial fibrillation. Similar risk factors and management
cases.management: Rate control, anticoagulation, consider catheter ablation for definitive treatment

cases.title: STEMI - Anterior Wall
key_features: Reciprocal ST depression in inferior leads
cases.clinical_context: MEDICAL EMERGENCY. Acute LAD occlusion. High risk of cardiogenic shock and death
cases.management: IMMEDIATE reperfusion: PCI within 90 min or fibrinolysis within 30 min. Dual antiplatelet, anticoagulation, beta-blocker, ACE-I, statin

cases.title: STEMI - Inferior Wall
key_features: ST elevation in II, III, aVF
Reciprocal ST depression in I, aVL
cases.clinical_context: RCA occlusion most common. Check right-sided leads (V4R) if hypotensive. Risk of AV block
cases.management: IMMEDIATE reperfusion. Caution with nitrates/morphine if RV involvement (preload-dependent)

cases.title: Left Bundle Branch Block (LBBB)
key_features: Broad, notched QRS in I, aVL, V5-V6 (M-shaped)
Absent Q waves in I, V5-V6
cases.clinical_context: Always pathological. Associated with CAD, HTN, cardiomyopathy, aortic stenosis. New LBBB with chest pain = STEMI equivalent
cases.management: Investigate underlying cause. If new LBBB + chest pain → treat as STEMI. Consider cardiac resynchronization therapy if heart failure

cases.title: Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB)
key_features: Wide, slurred S wave in I, V5-V6
ST depression and T wave inversion in V1-V3
cases.clinical_context: May be normal variant in young adults. Can indicate RV strain (PE), structural heart disease, or degenerative conduction disease
cases.management: Usually benign. Investigate if new, symptomatic, or with other ECG abnormalities

cases.title: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW)
cases.clinical_context: Accessory pathway (Bundle of Kent) causing ventricular pre-excitation. Risk of sudden cardiac death from AF with rapid conduction
cases.management: Asymptomatic: observation. Symptomatic SVT: catheter ablation. AVOID AV nodal blockers (adenosine, CCB, BB, digoxin) in AF with WPW → can precipitate VF

cases.title: Ventricular Tachycardia (VT)
cases.clinical_context: MEDICAL EMERGENCY. Often post-MI, cardiomyopathy, long QT. Can degenerate to VF
cases.management: Unstable: immediate synchronized cardioversion. Stable: amiodarone or procainamide. Correct electrolytes. Consider ICD

cases.title: Hyperkalemia
cases.clinical_context: MEDICAL EMERGENCY. K+ >6.5 mmol/L. Risk of cardiac arrest. Common in renal failure, medications (ACE-I, ARBs, spironolactone)
cases.management: URGENT: Calcium gluconate (membrane stabilization), insulin+glucose, salbutamol, calcium resonium, dialysis if severe

cases.title: Long QT Syndrome
cases.clinical_context: Risk of Torsades de Pointes and sudden cardiac death. Congenital (channelopathies) or acquired (medications, electrolytes)
cases.management: Stop QT-prolonging drugs. Correct electrolytes. Beta-blockers. ICD if high risk. Avoid triggers (exercise, loud noises)

cases.title: Pericarditis
key_features: Upright T waves with ST elevation
cases.clinical_context: Inflammation of pericardium. Viral most common. Positional chest pain, worse lying flat, better sitting forward. Pericardial rub
cases.management: NSAIDs + colchicine. Echo to check for effusion. Avoid anticoagulation (risk of hemorrhagic pericarditis)

cases.title: Brugada Syndrome Type 1
cases.clinical_context: Channelopathy (SCN5A mutation). Risk of sudden cardiac death from VF. Common in Southeast Asian males. Triggered by fever, alcohol
cases.management: ICD for survivors of cardiac arrest or syncope. Avoid triggers. Fever must be aggressively treated. Screening family members

cases.title: Mobitz Type II AV Block
cases.diagnosis: Second Degree AV Block - Mobitz Type II
cases.clinical_context: DANGEROUS. Infranodal disease. High risk of progression to complete heart block. Often post-MI or degenerative disease
cases.management: URGENT pacing (transvenous or transcutaneous). Often requires permanent pacemaker

cases.title: Complete Heart Block (3rd Degree)
key_features: No relationship between P and QRS
cases.clinical_context: MEDICAL EMERGENCY. Risk of asystole. Causes: MI, degenerative disease, medications, congenital
cases.management: URGENT pacing. Permanent pacemaker required. Atropine ineffective if infranodal
